#Text=TO HUBERT

#Text=Dear Hubert , if I ever found A wishing-carpet lying round , I ’d stand upon it , and I ’d say : ‘ Take me to Hubert , right away ! ’ And then we ’d travel very far To where the magic countries are That you and I will never see , And choose the loveliest gifts for you , from me .
#Text=But oh !
#Text=alack !
#Text=and well-a-day !
#Text=No wishing-carpets come my way .
#Text=I never found a Phoenix yet , And Psammeads are so hard to get !
#Text=So I give you nothing fine -- Only this book your book and mine , And hers , whose name by yours is set ; Your book , my book , the book of Margaret !
#Text=E. NESBIT DYMCHURCH
#Text=September , 1904
#Text=CONTENTS
#Text=1 The Egg 2 The Topless Tower
#Text=3 The Queen Cook 4
#Text=Two Bazaars 5 The Temple 6 Doing Good
#Text=7 Mews from Persia 8 The Cats , the Cow , and the Burglar 9 The Burglar ’s Bride 10
#Text=The Hole in the Carpet 11
#Text=The Beginning of the End 12
#Text=The End of the End
#Text=CHAPTER 1 .
#Text=THE EGG

#Text=It began with the day when it was almost the Fifth of November , and a doubt arose in some breast -- Robert ’s , I fancy -- as to the quality of the fireworks laid in for the Guy Fawkes celebration .
#Text=‘ They were jolly cheap , ’ said whoever it was , and I think it was Robert , ‘ and suppose they did n’t go off on the night ?
#Text=Those Prosser kids would have something to snigger about then . ’
#Text=‘ The ones I got are all right , ’ Jane said ;
#Text=‘ I know they are , because the man at the shop said they were worth thribble the money -- ’
#Text=‘ I ’m sure thribble is n’t grammar , ’ Anthea said .
#Text=‘ Of course it is n’t , ’ said Cyril ; ‘ one word ca n’t be grammar all by itself , so you need n’t be so jolly clever . ’

#Text=Anthea was rummaging in the corner-drawers of her mind for a very disagreeable answer , when she remembered what a wet day it was , and how the boys had been disappointed of that ride to London and back on the top of the tram , which their mother had promised them as a reward for not having once forgotten , for six whole days , to wipe their boots on the mat when they came home from school .
#Text=So Anthea only said , ‘ Do n’t be so jolly clever yourself , Squirrel .
#Text=And the fireworks look all right , and you ’ll have the eightpence that your tram fares did n’t cost to-day , to buy something more with .
#Text=You ought to get a perfectly lovely Catharine wheel for eightpence . ’
#Text=‘ I daresay , ’ said Cyril , coldly ; ‘ but it ’s not YOUR eightpence anyhow -- ’
#Text=‘ But look here , ’ said Robert , ‘ really now , about the fireworks .
#Text=We do n’t want to be disgraced before those kids next door .
#Text=They think because they wear red plush on Sundays no one else is any good . ’
#Text=‘ I would n’t wear plush if it was ever so -- unless it was black to be beheaded in , if I was Mary Queen of Scots , ’ said Anthea , with scorn .
#Text=Robert stuck steadily to his point .
#Text=One great point about Robert is the steadiness with which he can stick .
#Text=‘ I think we ought to test them , ’ he said .
#Text=‘ You young duffer , ’ said Cyril , ‘ fireworks are like postage-stamps .
#Text=You can only use them once . ’
#Text=‘ What do you suppose it means by “ Carter ’s tested seeds ” in the advertisement ? ’
#Text=There was a blank silence .
#Text=Then Cyril touched his forehead with his finger and shook his head .
#Text=‘ A little wrong here , ’ he said .
#Text=‘ I was always afraid of that with poor Robert .
#Text=All that cleverness , you know , and being top in algebra so often -- it ’s bound to tell -- ’
#Text=‘ Dry up , ’ said Robert , fiercely .
#Text=‘ Do n’t you see ?
#Text=You ca n’t TEST seeds if you do them ALL .
#Text=You just take a few here and there , and if those grow you can feel pretty sure the others will be -- what do you call it ? -- Father told me -- “up to sample ” .
#Text=Do n’t you think we ought to sample the fire-works ?
#Text=Just shut our eyes and each draw one out , and then try them . ’
#Text=‘ But it ’s raining cats and dogs , ’ said Jane .
#Text=‘ And Queen Anne is dead , ’ rejoined Robert .
#Text=No one was in a very good temper .
#Text=‘ We need n’t go out to do them ; we can just move back the table , and let them off on the old tea-tray we play toboggans with .

#Text=I do n’t know what YOU think , but I think it ’s time we did something , and that would be really useful ; because then we should n’t just HOPE the fireworks would make those Prossers sit up -- we should KNOW . ’
#Text=‘ It WOULD be something to do , ’ Cyril owned with languid approval .
#Text=So the table was moved back .
#Text=And then the hole in the carpet , that had been near the window till the carpet was turned round , showed most awfully .
#Text=But Anthea stole out on tip-toe , and got the tray when cook was n’t looking , and brought it in and put it over the hole .
#Text=Then all the fireworks were put on the table , and each of the four children shut its eyes very tight and put out its hand and grasped something .

#Text=Robert took a cracker , Cyril and Anthea had Roman candles ; but Jane ’s fat paw closed on the gem of the whole collection , the Jack-in-the-box that had cost two shillings , and one at least of the party -- I will not say which , because it was sorry afterwards -- declared that Jane had done it on purpose .
#Text=Nobody was pleased .

#Text=For the worst of it was that these four children , with a very proper dislike of anything even faintly bordering on the sneakish , had a law , unalterable as those of the Medes and Persians , that one had to stand by the results of a toss-up , or a drawing of lots , or any other appeal to chance , however much one might happen to dislike the way things were turning out .
